abstract.text: Display view controllers using different techniques, and pass data between them during transitions.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: You change your appâ€™s interface by presenting and dismissing view controllers. Every window has a root view controller, which provides the initial content for your window. Presenting a new view controller changes that content by installing a new set of views in the window. When you no longer need the view controller, dismissing it removes its views from the window. You present view controllers in one of these ways:
Configure presentations visually in your storyboard.
Embed them in a container view controller.
Call methods of
directly.
Each technique gives you different amounts of control over the presentation and dismissal process.

content.text: Specify presentations visually in your storyboard file

inlineContent.text: Using segues in your storyboard is the recommended way to present and dismiss view controllers. A segue is a visual representation of a transition from one view controller to another. A segue starts with an action such as a button tap or table-row selection in the initial view controller. When that action occurs, UIKit creates the view controller at the other end of the segue and presents it automatically. Because you create and configure segues in your storyboard, you can change them very quickly.
Start a segue from any object that implements an action method, such as a control or gesture recognizer. You may also start segues from table rows and collection view cells.
Right-click the control or object in your current view controller.
Drag the cursor to the view controller you want to present.
Select the kind of segue you want from the list that Xcode provides.

The storyboard shows segues as an arrow between two view controllers. Selecting the segue displays information about it, including the kind of presentation you want UIKit to perform. You can modify the presentation type or configure additional details, such as a segue identifier. You use this information at runtime to customize the segue further, as described in
For information about how to dismiss a view controller in your storyboards, see

content.text: Let the current context define the presentation technique

inlineContent.text: Reusing the same view controller in multiple places creates a potential problem: presenting it in different ways based on the current context. For example, you might want to embed it in a navigation controller in one instance, but present it modally in another. UIKit solves this problem with the
and
methods of
, which present the view controller in the most appropriate way for the current context.
When you call the
or
method, UIKit determines the most appropriate context for the presentation. Specifically, it calls the
method to search for a parent view controller that implements the corresponding
method. If a parent implements the method and wants to handle the presentation, UIKit calls the parentâ€™s implementation. A
objectâ€™s implementation of the
method pushes the new view controller onto its navigation stack. If no view controller handles the presentation, UIKit presents the view controller modally.
The following code example creates a view controller and shows it using the
method. The code is equivalent to creating a segue with the kind set to Show.
After showing a view controller, use the current context to determine how to dismiss it. Calling the
method might not always be the most appropriate option. For example, donâ€™t call that method if a navigation controller added the view controller to its navigation stack. Instead, use the
, and

properties to determine the current context, and to take appropriate actions in response. That response might also include modifying your view controllerâ€™s UI to hide a Done button or other controls for dismissing the UI.
When implementing a custom container view controller, implement the
and
methods to handle presentations. For more information, see

content.text: Embed a view controller inside a container view controller

inlineContent.text: A container view controller embeds content from one or more child view controllers, and presents the combined interface onscreen. Embedding a child view controller presents it using a container-specific approach. For example, a navigation controller initially positions the child view controller offscreen and then animates it into position onscreen.
The standard UIKit container view controllers work with segues and the
and

methods to embed view controllers as children. They also define additional API for adding and removing child view controllers programmatically. Use segues and the show methods to handle most transitions. Use the methods in the following table to perform one-time configuration of your view controller, for example when restoring your appâ€™s UI to a previous state.
Container
Presentation options
UISplitViewController
Replace the two initial view controllers using the
property. The first (primary) view controller appears in the leading pane and the second (detail) view controller appears in the trailing pane.
UINavigationController
Replace the contents of the navigation stack using the
property. Add or remove a subset of view controllers simultaneously using the
method.
UITabBarController
Replace the initial tabs using the
property. Change the current tabs dynamically using the
method.
UIPageViewController
Provide all child view controllers using a
object.
Always use the container view controllerâ€™s API to remove or replace a presented view controller.

Use modal presentations to create temporary interruptions in your appâ€™s workflow, such as prompting the user for important information. A modal presentation covers the current view controller wholly or partially, depending on the presentation style you use. Full-screen presentations always replace the previous content, but sheet-style presentations may leave some of the underlying content visible. The actual appearance of each presentation style depends on the current trait environment.
To configure a modal presentation, create the new view controller and call the
method. That method animates the new view controller into position using the
style and the
transition animation. To change the styles, modify the
and
properties of the view controller you present. The following code example changes both of these styles to create a full-screen presentation using a cross-dissolve animation.
To dismiss a modally presented view controller, call the view controllerâ€™s
method.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
A view controller that specializes in managing a collection view.
A set of methods for adapting the contents of your view controllers to size and trait changes.
The default presentation style chosen by the system.
A container view controller that defines a stack-based scheme for navigating hierarchical content.
Replaces the view controllers currently managed by the navigation controller with the specified items.
The view controllers currently on the navigation stack.
The
protocol is adopted by an object that provides view controllers to the page view controller on an as-needed basis, in response to navigation gestures.
The array of view controllers the split view controller manages.
Sets the root view controllers of the tab bar controller.
An array of the root view controllers displayed by the tab bar interface.
A view controller that specializes in managing a table view.
An object that manages a view hierarchy for your UIKit app.
Dismisses the view controller that was presented modally by the view controller.
The presentation style for modal view controllers.
The transition style to use when presenting the view controller.
The nearest ancestor in the view controller hierarchy that is a navigation controller.
Presents a view controller modally.
The view controller that presented this view controller.
Presents a view controller in a primary context.
Presents a view controller in a secondary (or detail) context.
The nearest ancestor in the view controller hierarchy that is a split view controller.
The nearest ancestor in the view controller hierarchy that is a tab bar controller.
Returns the view controller that responds to the action.
Create a composite interface by combining content from one or more view controllers with other custom views.
